NewsDetail.Name: Grade Center Gotchas – tips to avoid a catastrophe
NewsDetail.Title: Grade Center Gotchas – tips to avoid a catastrophe
NewsDetail.Abstract: "In this installment of the Simplifying I-Learn series I’ll provide 10 recommendations on how to avoid these Grade Center catastrophes. These are small and common user errors that can cause big problems."
NewsDetail.Author: Orren Squires
NewsDetail.BodyCopy:
It’s a fact - ask 10 faculty and you’ll get 15 Grade Center catastrophe stories.  We’ve all heard them or even worse, experienced them.  These range from “All my grades were wrong and I had to fill out grade change cards” to “What happened to my exam scores?” 

Academic Technology, with the help of our brethren in Information Technology, take these catastrophic stories very seriously and spend a lot of time investigating the root cause.  The bad news:  most were caused by user error.  The good news:  it means we can at least partially fix the problem by sharing the Gotchas. 

In this installment of the Simplifying I-Learn series I’ll provide 10 recommendations on how to avoid these Grade Center catastrophes.  These are small and common user errors that can cause big problems. 

Gotcha #1 - Selecting “Remove Column” from the column drop down menu:  A warning is given but many people click OK without reading the warning.  This Gotcha is easy to do but results in a lost assignment or exam for all students.  The only recovery possible is if the item was already scored the day before this mistake.  Most instructors make this mistake when trying to remove duplicate columns caused by a course copy – they simply remove the wrong one.

Gotcha #2 – “Clear attempts for all users”:  Like Gotcha #1, the column drop down menu item “Clear attempts for all users” does exactly what it says.  What makes this one particularly catastrophic is that there is no warning – you click it and you got it.  (I almost find this humorous given the number of times I have to click OK everywhere else.)  When an exam has only one attempt, clearing the last attempt means clearing the exam immediately.  Like #1 the only recovery possible is if the item was already scored the day before the mistake.

Gotcha #3 – “Hide results for this test completely from instructor and Grade Center”:  This one has tagged several instructors recently.  This ugly little checkmark option is found when creating an exam or modifying the test options.  Unfortunately, many instructors miss the warning found right underneath the option.  The key phrase in the warning is “this choice can not be reversed later without losing all attempts.”  No successful work-around has been found and checking this option really does make it so the test is completely hidden from the instructor and Grade Center.

Gotcha #4 – More than 25 items in a category:  The actual number varies a little but a maximum of 25 items in a category is the safe number.  This means item 26 may or may not be included in the total or weighted calculations.  There are absolutely no warnings that this is the case, so keep categories below 25 items to be safe.  The 25-item limit also applies to uncategorized items.  Don’t have more than 25 uncategorized items in Grade Center or it will start ignoring the extras.  This tricky little Gotcha will cause inaccurate grade totals if ignored.

Gotcha #5 – Running totals:  By default this option is “Yes” when creating a calculated column and for most of the semester this is fine.  Here is the Gotcha…if you don’t enter a zero for a missed item then Grade Center ignores that item when calculating grades. 

Here’s why – running totals only calculate the grade based on what the student has attempted to submit.  When a student misses an assignment, Grade Center assumes the student has not attempted to submit anything and therefore ignores that item in the calculation. 

If you use total points for your grades this won’t affect you since your grade is based on total points earned.  However, if you use weighted grades, percentages, or letter grades in the totals column this Gotcha can bite hard.  It is quite common for a good student to get the same grade as a student who barely turns anything in, due to this hitch.

The workaround is to either enter zeros for missed assignments OR change the running totals option to “No” before submitting final grades.  Also, be sure this option is set the same for all total columns you may have that calculate into the final total.

Gotcha #6 – Categories and missing items:  This is probably the hardest to find and the easiest Gotcha trap to fall into.  When creating a category in Grade Center, be sure every item you want in the category is actually included.  It is easy to forget to assign an item to a category and have it really mess up the final totals.

A typical example:  You create a quiz category and weight it so that quizzes are 40% of the final grade.  You give a total of 15 quizzes in the semester but forget to add quizzes 6 and 12 to the quiz category.  Since the category is weighted, these two uncategorized quizzes are ignored.  One way to find the error is to look at the “Column Information” for each column item and be sure it is categorized the way you intended.

A variant of this Gotcha happens when an instructor has two categories with the same name and places some items in each one.  In the totals column only one category is selected which means the items in the other category are ignored.

Gotcha #7 - Equally Vs. Proportionally weighted grades:  A good understanding of these two choices is critical for the instructor who decides to weight grades.  The default is equally graded but many don’t pay attention to what that really means. 

Equally weighted grades means that each item in the category is worth the same regardless of the number of points assigned.   This means if a student gets 100% on a 5-point attendance quiz and 80% on a 30-point chapter quiz, the final grade is 90%.

Proportionally weighted grades means each item is weighted according to its point value.  Now that 30-point chapter quiz is worth 6 times as much as that 5-point attendance quiz.  The same student now gets a final grade of 82.9%.

Gotcha #8 – Adding an average column:  It’s not hard to accidently select the “Average” menu item when adding a calculated column.  Unfortunately, the screen you get looks just like the “Totals” menu item and unless you read carefully it is easy proceed without realizing your mistake.  Unfortunately, this catches a few instructors unaware and throws the resulting grades way off.  The only way to catch this Gotcha is to select “Modify Column” from the column dropdown menu and look at the page title – everything else on the page looks exactly like a totals or weighted column page.

Gotcha #9 – Student View vs. Instructor View:  What you see is not what the student sees.  Selecting the “Hide” option in the column dropdown menu does not hide it from the students.  Similarly, the “Show” option under “Organize Grade Center” doesn’t show the scores to the students.  Many instructors hide columns they are not using but don’t realize the students can still see them.  The only way to change what a student sees or doesn’t see is to select “Modify Column” in each of the column dropdown menus, and then select the appropriate radio button.

Gotcha #10 – “Include this column in Grade Center calculations:”  It may sound pretty straight forward but when we copy courses from one semester to the next it is a simple thing to miss.  There have been several instructors who decided to not give a particular assignment one semester and then used it the next.  Unfortunately they kept the item in Grade Center and just turned this option off.  The course is copied for the next semester and its still off.  Basically the student did the work but didn’t get the credit.  It’s even better for the student who decided to not do the work but wasn’t penalized.

I hope these top 10 Gotchas will help you avoid most of the catastrophes you hear about.  The interface for Grade Center may not be great but for the short term education is our only option.  If you have questions or don’t understand anything in this article please feel free to call the helpdesk at (208)496-9000.
